chapter_3_Streams

Class Recipe_3_7_Counting_Elements

  • java.lang.Object
    • chapter_3_Streams.Recipe_3_7_Counting_Elements

  • public class Recipe_3_7_Counting_Elements
extends java.lang.Object

    (3.7.) Counting Elements


    1. TO DO

      - you want to know how many elements are in a stream

    2. HOW

      - use the Stream.count() or Collectors.counting() methods

    3. EQ.

      • countingElementsInAStream() - counting elements in a stream
    See Also:
    Recipe_4_6_Downstream_Collectors

      • countingElementsInAStream

        protected static void countingElementsInAStream()
        ◊◊◊ Counting Elements in a Stream ◊◊◊
        Using the count method on Stream:

        For this method, all the elements in the stream are mapped to 1 as a long, then the mapToLong method produces a LongStream, which has a sum method. (Map all the elements to one and add them up.) 
        
 long count = Stream.of(1, 3, 5, 7, 9).count();
 // Implementation of count():
 mapToLong(e -> 1L).sum();
        Using the counting method on Collectors:
        The Collectors methods are intended for downstream post-processing of a partitioningBy or groupingBy operation. 
        
 Long counted = Stream.of(1, 3, 5, 7, 9).collect(Collectors.counting());
 Map<Boolean, Long> collectedValues = Stream.of("aa", "bbbb", "c", "dddd", "ee")
          .collect(Collectors.partitioningBy(s -> s.length() % 2 == 0, // Predicate
                                             Collectors.counting())); // Downstream collector
